sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Cobalamin deficiency: normal absorption, 1000 mcg/day ORALLY; if oral route not adequate, initial treatment same as for pernicious anemia; chronic treatment should be with oral B12 preparation
  • Cobalamin deficiency: malabsorption, 100 mcg IM or deep SC injection daily for 6 or 7 days; if clinical improvement and reticulocyte response, give same amount on alternate days for 7 doses; then every 3 to 4 days for another 2 to 3 wk; then 100 mcg monthly for life (manufacturer dosing)
  • Cobalamin deficiency: malabsorption, 1000 mcg IM daily for 10 days OR daily for 3 to 7 days followed by weekly injection for 3 to 4 weeks; then monthly have been reported in the literature
  • Cobalamin deficiency: nasal spray; 500 mcg INTRANASALLY in one nostril once weekly
  • Cobalamin deficiency; Prophylaxis: (nasal spray, Nascobal(R)) 500 mcg spray INTRANASALLY into one nostril once weekly
  • Cobalamin deficiency; Prophylaxis: (nasal spray, CaloMist(TM)) 25 mcg spray INTRANASALLY each nostril daily, total dose 50 mcg per day; dose may be increased to one spray each nostril twice daily when once daily is inadequate
  • Cobalamin deficiency; Prophylaxis: (sublingual tablet) 2500 mcg SL once daily
  • Cobalamin deficiency; Prophylaxis: (time-released tablet) 1500 mcg ORALLY once daily
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia: 400 mcg/day ORALLY with folic acid
  • Malabsorption of cyanocobalamin; Diagnosis - Schilling test: 18.5 to 37 kBq (0.5 to 1 mCi) cyanocobalamin Co 57 ORALLY, followed by 1000 mcg cyanocobalamin IM 2 hr later
  • Malabsorption of cyanocobalamin; Diagnosis - Schilling test: flushing dose, 1000 mcg IM
  • Pernicious anemia: 100 mcg IM or deep SC injection daily for 6 or 7 days; if clinical improvement and reticulocyte response, give same amount on alternate days for 7 doses; then every 3 to 4 days for another 2 to 3 wk; then 100 mcg monthly for life (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pernicious anemia: malabsorption, 1000 mcg IM daily for 10 days OR daily for 3 to 7 days followed by weekly injection for 3 to 4 weeks; then monthly have been reported in the literature
  • Pernicious anemia: nasal spray; 500 mcg INTRANASALLY in one nostril once weekly for maintenance of normal hematologic status

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Cobalamin deficiency: 1000 mcg/day ORALLY, IM route is preferred; 30 to 50 mcg IM daily for 2 or more wk; then 100 mcg monthly to sustain remission
  • Pernicious anemia: 30 to 50 mcg IM daily for 2 or more wk; then 100 mcg monthly to sustain remission

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic impairment: an increase in dose (decrease in dosing interval) may be required
  • renal impairment: an increase in dose (decrease in dosing interval) may be required

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cobalamin deficiency
  • Cobalamin deficiency; Prophylaxis
  • Malabsorption of cyanocobalamin; Diagnosis - Schilling test
  • Pernicious anemia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • AIDS virus infection associated with pregnancy
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to cobalt, B12 products, or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylactic shock; has been reported (injection)
  • angioedema; has been reported (injection)
  • chronic nasal symptoms; potential for erratic or blunted absorption (intranasal)
  • concomitant intranasal medications; potential for erratic cyanocobalamin absorption (intranasal)
  • concomitant bone marrow suppressants; may blunt therapeutic response (intranasal)
  • folate deficiency; not indicated, may blunt therapeutic response
  • infection; may blunt therapeutic response (intranasal)
  • intravenous use; may result in nearly all of the dose being lost in the urine; should be avoided
  • iron deficiency; may blunt therapeutic response (intranasal)
  • Leber's disease, early (hereditary optic nerve atrophy); may increase risk of optic atrophy, potentially sudden and severe; use is not recommended
  • megaloblastic anemia, severe; when treated intensely with cyanocobalamin, may increase risk of hypokalemia, thrombocytosis, and sudden death
  • nasal pathology, significant; potential for erratic or blunted absorption (intranasal)
  • premature infants; contains benzyl alcohol; increased risk of fatal gasping syndrome (injection)
  • renal impairment; prolonged parenteral administration increases risk of aluminum toxicity, particularly in premature infants (injection)
  • uremia; may blunt therapeutic response (intranasal)
  • vitamin B12 concentrations, declining or abnormally low with maximum dose; may produce irreversible neurological damage if inadequate treatment for longer than 3 months

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (12%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (12%), Headache (12%)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (12%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Congestive heart failure, Peripheral vascular disease, Pulmonary edema
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Cyanocobalamin, the most widely used form of Vitamin B(12), exhibits a hematopoietic activity similar to the anti-anemia factor found in purified extract of the liver. It is vital to cell reproduction, growth, and synthesis of myelin and nucleoprotein. It also plays a significant role in the metabolism of energy in the body.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Intramuscular: time to peak concentration, 1 h
  • Intranasal: time to peak concentration, 1 h to 2 h
  • Subcutaneous: quantitatively and rapidly absorbed
  • Bioavailability: (Intranasal), 8.9% (7.1% to 11.2%) relative to intramuscular injection

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• distributed primarily in the liver and bone marrow
  • Protein binding: yes

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile
  • Renal: 50% to 98%, more rapidly in IV route

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    (injection) for IM or SUBQ use only; do not give IV
  • Nasal
    • prime Nascobal(R) nasal spray actuator initially and before each use; administer at least 1 hr before or 1 hr after ingestion of hot foods or liquids
    • prime CaloMist(TM) nasal spray pump prior to the first use; re-prime if the pump is not used for 5 or more days; separate administration with other intranasal medication by several hours
  • Oral
    • (time-released) preferably take with a meal
    • (time-released) do not take within 2 hr of medications
    • (sublingual) place tablet under tongue for 30 sec before swallowing

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• (injection) hematocrit, reticulocyte count, vitamin B12, folate, iron; prior to administration
  • (nasal) serum potassium, CBC

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Injection Solution: 1000 MCG/ML
    • Intramuscular Solution: 100 MCG/ML, 1000 MCG/ML
    • Mucous Membrane Lozenge/Troche: 100 MCG, 250 MCG, 500 MCG
    • Oral Tablet: 50 MCG, 100 MCG, 250 MCG, 500 MCG, 1000 MCG
    • Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG, 1500 MCG
    • Sublingual Tablet: 1000 MCG, 2500 MCG, 5000 MCG
  • B-12-SL
    Sublingual Tablet, Disintegrating: 1000 MCG
  • Cobolin-M
    Intramuscular Solution: 1000 MCG/ML
  • Depo-Cobolin
    Intramuscular Solution: 1000 MCG/ML
  • Good Neighbor Pharmacy Vitamin B12
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG
  • Leader Natural Vitamin B12
    • Oral Tablet: 500 MCG
    • Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG
  • Mason Natural B-12
    Sublingual Tablet: 5000 MCG
  • Nascobal
    Nasal Spray: 500 MCG/0.1 ML
  • Nature's Blend B12
    Sublingual Tablet: 2500 MCG
  • Neuroforte-R
    Intramuscular Solution: 1000 MCG/ML
  • PharmAssure Vitamin B-12
    • Oral Tablet: 500 MCG
    • Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG, 2000 MCG
  • Rite Aid Vitamin B-12
    Oral Solution: 1000 MCG/ML
  • Rite Aid Vitamin B-12
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG, 2000 MCG
  • Sundown Naturals B12
    Sublingual Tablet: 2500 MCG
  • The Medicine Shoppe Natural Vitamin B12
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 1000 MCG
  • The Medicine Shoppe Vitamin B12
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 2000 MCG
  • Twelve Resin-K
    Oral Tablet: 1000 MCG
  • Vita #12
    Intramuscular Solution: 1000 MCG/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patients using the intranasal form to report nasal congestion or rhinitis, as this may affect drug absorption.
  • This drug may cause transient diarrhea or headache.
  • Patient should take extended-release tablets with a meal and not within 2 h of other medications.
  • Advise patient to take the intranasal gel at least 1 h before or 1 h after ingesting hot foods or liquids.
  • Tell patient to leave sublingual tablet, lozenge, or spray in mouth or under tongue for 30 seconds before swallowing.
  • Patient should not drink alcohol while taking this drug.
